context_text:
Consistency: Messages should be delivered in the order they were sent.
Availability: The system should be highly available. However, the availability can be compromised in the interest of consistency.
Security: The system must be secure via end-to-end encryption. The end-to-end encryption ensures that only the two communicating parties can see the content of messages. Nobody in between, not even WhatsApp, should have access.
Scalability: The system should be highly scalable to support an ever-increasing number of users and messages per day.
Capacity Estimation
Storage Estimation:
100 billion messages are shared through WhatsApp per day and each message takes 100 bytes on average
100 billion/day∗100 Bytes = 10 TB/day
For 30 days, the storage capacity would become the following:
---
Bandwidth Estimation:
According to the storage capacity estimation, our service will get 10TB of data each day, giving us a bandwidth of 926 Mb/s.
10 TB/86400sec ≈ 926Mb/s

Number of servers estimation:
WhatsApp handles around 10 million connections on a single server, which seems quite high for a server.
No. of servers = Total connections per day/No. of connections per server = 2 billion/10 million = 200 servers
So, according to the above estimates, we require 200 chat servers.

Requirements
The WhatsApp messenger design should meet below requirements:
---
Functional Requirement
Conversation: The system should support one-on-one and group conversations between users.
Acknowledgment: The system should support message delivery acknowledgment, such as sent, delivered, and read.
Sharing: The system should support sharing of media files, such as images, videos, and audio.
Chat storage: The system must support the persistent storage of chat messages when a user is offline until the successful delivery of messages.
Push notifications: The system should be able to notify offline users of new messages once their status becomes online.
Non-Functional Requirement
Low latency: Users should be able to receive messages with low latency.
Consistency: Messages should be delivered in the order they were sent.
---
Now, here comes the responsibility of the group service. The group service keeps all information about users in each group in the system. It has all the information about each group, including user IDs, group ID, status, group icon, number of users, and so on. This service resides on top of the MySQL database cluster, with multiple secondary replicas distributed geographically. A Redis cache server also exists to cache data from the MySQL servers. Both geographically distributed replicas and Redis cache aid in reducing latency.

The group message handler communicates with the group service to retrieve data of Group/A users. In the last step, the group message handler follows the same process as a WebSocket server and delivers the message to each user.
---
4. Support for Group messages
Since user A is connected to a WebSocket server, it sends a message to the message service intended for Group A.The message service sends the message to Kafka with other specific information about the group. The message is saved there for further processing. In Kafka terminology, a group can be a topic, and the senders and receivers can be producers and consumers, respectively.
---
API Design
Send message
sendMessage(message_ID, sender_ID, reciever_ID, type, text=none, media_object=none, document=none)
---
The following steps describe the communication between both clients:

User A and user B create a communication channel with the chat server.
User A sends a message to the chat server.
Upon receiving the message, the chat server acknowledges back to user A.
The chat server sends the message to user B and stores the message in the database if the receiver’s status is offline.
User B sends an acknowledgment to the chat server.
The chat server notifies user A that the message has been successfully delivered.
When user B reads the message, the application notifies the chat server.
The chat server notifies user A that user B has read the message.

The WebSocket manager is responsible for maintaining a mapping between an active user and a port assigned to the user. 1. Connection with Websocket Server
In WhatsApp, each active device is connected with a WebSocket server via WebSocket protocol. A WebSocket server keeps the connection open with all the active (online) users. Since one server isn’t enough to handle billions of devices, there should be enough servers to handle billions of users.
---

Message service is a repository of messages on top of the Mnesia database cluster. It acts as an interface to the Mnesia database for other services interacting with the databases. It is responsible for storing and retrieving messages from the Mnesia database. It also deletes messages from the Mnesia database after a configurable amount of time. response_text:
1. Low Latency:
To ensure low latency in the system, the design includes multiple secondary replicas of the MySQL database cluster distributed geographically. This helps in reducing latency by providing a closer location for users from different regions. Additionally, Redis cache is used to cache data from the MySQL servers, which further reduces latency.
2. Consistency:
To ensure that messages are delivered in the order they were sent, the system uses Kafka as a messaging system. Kafka is designed to handle high-throughput and provides guarantees for message ordering and delivery.
3. Support for Group Messages:
The group message handler communicates with the group service to retrieve data of Group/A users. The system uses Kafka to store and process messages intended for a specific group. This allows for efficient handling of messages intended for multiple users in a group.
4. Download Media File:
The media file is compressed and encrypted on the device side before being sent to the asset service. The asset service assigns an ID to the file and stores it on blob storage. When a user requests a media file, the asset service sends the ID of the file to the receiver via the message service. The receiver then downloads the file from the blob storage using the ID.
5. Microservices Architecture:
The system uses a microservices architecture, where each service has ownership of its own data model. This allows for easier scaling and decoupling of services.
6. Connection with WebSocket Server:
Each active device is connected to a WebSocket server via the WebSocket protocol. The system should have enough WebSocket servers to handle billions of users.
7. Media File Processing:
The asset service is responsible for sending and receiving media files. It compresses and encrypts media files on the device side before storing them on blob storage. When a user requests a media file, the asset service sends the ID of the file to the receiver via the message service. The receiver then downloads the file from the blob storage using the ID.
8. Message Service:
The message service is a repository of messages on top of the Mnesia database cluster. It acts as an interface to the Mnesia database for other services interacting with the databases. It stores and retrieves messages from the Mnesia database, and deletes messages after a configurable amount of time.
9. Non-Functional Requirements:
The system must support low latency and consistency in message delivery. The system must also support the ability to send and receive media files.

Since user A is connected to a WebSocket server, it sends a message to the message service intended for Group A.The message service sends the message to Kafka with other specific information about the group. The message is saved there for further processing. In Kafka terminology, a group can be a topic, and the senders and receivers can be producers and consumers, respectively.
---
API Design
Send message
sendMessage(message_ID, sender_ID, reciever_ID, type, text=none, media_object=none, document=none)
---
The following steps describe the communication between both clients:

User A and user B create a communication channel with the chat server.
User A sends a message to the chat server.
Upon receiving the message, the chat server acknowledges back to user A.
The chat server sends the message to user B and stores the message in the database if the receiver’s status is offline.
User B sends an acknowledgment to the chat server.
The chat server notifies user A that the message has been successfully delivered.
When user B reads the message, the application notifies the chat server.
The chat server notifies user A that user B has read the message.
Data Model Design:
Data-Model-Design
---
The responsibility of each of these servers is to provide a port to every online user. The mapping between servers, ports, and users is stored in the WebSocket manager that resides on top of a cluster of the data store. In this case, that’s Redis.

2. Send or receive messages
The WebSocket manager is responsible for maintaining a mapping between an active user and a port assigned to the user. Whenever a user is connected to another WebSocket server, this information will be updated in the data store. A WebSocket server also communicates with another service called message service.
---

Architecture
We will be using microservices architecture since it will make it easier to horizontally scale and decouple our services. Each service will have ownership of its own data model.

Low Level Design (LLD) of System Design
Low-Level-Design(LLD)-of-WhatsApp-Messenger

1. Connection with Websocket Server
In WhatsApp, each active device is connected with a WebSocket server via WebSocket protocol. A WebSocket server keeps the connection open with all the active (online) users. Since one server isn’t enough to handle billions of devices, there should be enough servers to handle billions of users.
---
The media file is compressed and encrypted on the device side.
The compressed and encrypted file is sent to the asset service to store the file on blob storage.
The asset service assigns an ID that’s communicated with the sender. The asset service also maintains a hash for each file to avoid duplication of content on the blob storage.
For example, if a user wants to upload an image that’s already there in the blob storage, the image won’t be uploaded. Instead, the same ID is forwarded to the receiver.
The asset service sends the ID of media files to the receiver via the message service. The receiver downloads the media file from the blob storage using the ID.
The content is loaded onto a CDN if the asset service receives a large number of requests for some particular content.
---
This API is used to send a text message from a sender to a receiver by making a POST API call to the /messages API endpoint. Generally, the sender’s and receiver’s IDs are their phone numbers.

Get Message
getMessage(user_Id)

Using this API call, users can fetch all unread messages when they come online after being offline for some time.

Upload File
uploadFile(file_type, file)

We can upload media files via the uploadFile API by making a POST request to the /v1/media API endpoint. A successful response returns an ID that’s forwarded to the receiver.

Download Media File
downloadFile(user_id, file_id)

context_text:
Consistency: Messages should be delivered in the order they were sent.
Availability: The system should be highly available. However, the availability can be compromised in the interest of consistency.
Security: The system must be secure via end-to-end encryption. The end-to-end encryption ensures that only the two communicating parties can see the content of messages. Nobody in between, not even WhatsApp, should have access.
Scalability: The system should be highly scalable to support an ever-increasing number of users and messages per day.
Capacity Estimation
Storage Estimation:
100 billion messages are shared through WhatsApp per day and each message takes 100 bytes on average
100 billion/day∗100 Bytes = 10 TB/day
For 30 days, the storage capacity would become the following:
---
Bandwidth Estimation:
According to the storage capacity estimation, our service will get 10TB of data each day, giving us a bandwidth of 926 Mb/s.
10 TB/86400sec ≈ 926Mb/s

Number of servers estimation:
WhatsApp handles around 10 million connections on a single server, which seems quite high for a server.
No. of servers = Total connections per day/No. of connections per server = 2 billion/10 million = 200 servers
So, according to the above estimates, we require 200 chat servers.

Functional Requirement
Conversation: The system should support one-on-one and group conversations between users.
Acknowledgment: The system should support message delivery acknowledgment, such as sent, delivered, and read.
Sharing: The system should support sharing of media files, such as images, videos, and audio.
Chat storage: The system must support the persistent storage of chat messages when a user is offline until the successful delivery of messages.
Push notifications: The system should be able to notify offline users of new messages once their status becomes online.
Non-Functional Requirement
Low latency: Users should be able to receive messages with low latency.
Consistency: Messages should be delivered in the order they were sent.

response_text:
The system you are designing is a messaging platform with features such as one-on-one and group conversations, message delivery acknowledgment, sharing of media files, and push notifications. You have identified several servers and services that will be involved in the communication process, including WebSocket servers, message service, asset service, and CDN.

Here are some suggestions for improving the design:

1. Use a distributed database: Instead of relying on a single Redis instance, consider using a distributed database like Apache Cassandra or Amazon DynamoDB. This will provide better scalability and fault tolerance as the system grows.
2. Implement message queuing: To handle high traffic and prevent bottlenecks, consider implementing message queuing using a message broker like RabbitMQ or Apache Kafka. This will allow messages to be stored in a queue and processed when there are available resources.
3. Use load balancing: To distribute the workload across multiple servers, consider using load balancing techniques such as round-robin or least connections. This will ensure that no single server is overwhelmed with requests.
4. Implement message deduplication: To avoid sending duplicate messages to users who are already aware of them, consider implementing message deduplication at the message service level. This can be done using a variety of techniques, such as message IDs or timestamps.
5. Use content delivery networks (CDNs): To reduce latency and improve performance, consider using CDNs to cache media files and other assets. This will allow users to access the content more quickly and reduce the load on the backend servers.
6. Implement a message expiration policy: To prevent old messages from clogging up the system, consider implementing a message expiration policy that automatically deletes messages after a certain period of time.
7. Use user authentication and authorization: To ensure that only authorized users can access the messaging platform, consider implementing user authentication and authorization using OAuth or another security protocol. This will provide an additional layer of security and prevent unauthorized access to the system.
8. Monitoring and logging: Consider implementing monitoring and logging capabilities to track system performance and identify potential issues before they become critical. This can be done using tools like Prometheus, Grafana, or ELK Stack.
9. Implement message versioning: To handle version conflicts when multiple users are editing a message simultaneously, consider implementing message versioning. This will allow the system to keep track of multiple versions of a message and ensure that only the latest version is stored in the database.
10. Use a messaging protocol: To standardize the communication between clients and servers, consider using a messaging protocol like WebSocket or MQTT. This will provide a consistent interface for clients to communicate with servers and improve the overall performance of the system.

Since user A is connected to a WebSocket server, it sends a message to the message service intended for Group A.The message service sends the message to Kafka with other specific information about the group. The message is saved there for further processing. In Kafka terminology, a group can be a topic, and the senders and receivers can be producers and consumers, respectively.

The following steps describe the communication between both clients:

User A and user B create a communication channel with the chat server.
User A sends a message to the chat server.
Upon receiving the message, the chat server acknowledges back to user A.
The chat server sends the message to user B and stores the message in the database if the receiver’s status is offline.
User B sends an acknowledgment to the chat server.
The chat server notifies user A that the message has been successfully delivered.
When user B reads the message, the application notifies the chat server.
The chat server notifies user A that user B has read the message.

Functional Requirement
Conversation: The system should support one-on-one and group conversations between users.
Acknowledgment: The system should support message delivery acknowledgment, such as sent, delivered, and read.
Sharing: The system should support sharing of media files, such as images, videos, and audio.
Chat storage: The system must support the persistent storage of chat messages when a user is offline until the successful delivery of messages.
Push notifications: The system should be able to notify offline users of new messages once their status becomes online.
Non-Functional Requirement
Low latency: Users should be able to receive messages with low latency.
Consistency: Messages should be delivered in the order they were sent.

The system also supports sharing of media files, such as images, videos, and audio, and provides push notifications to notify offline users of new messages once their status becomes online. The system's design meets the functional and non-functional requirements mentioned in the question.

Storage Estimation:
100 billion messages are shared through WhatsApp per day and each message takes 100 bytes on average
100 billion/day∗100 Bytes = 10 TB/day

Bandwidth Estimation:
According to the storage capacity estimation, our service will get 10TB of data each day, giving us a bandwidth of 926 Mb/s.
10 TB/86400sec ≈ 926Mb/s

Number of servers estimation:
WhatsApp handles around 10 million connections on a single server, which seems quite high for a server.
No. of servers = Total connections per day/No. of connections per server = 2 billion/10 million = 200 servers
So, according to the above estimates, we require 200 chat servers.

Low Level Design (LLD) of System Design
Low-Level-Design(LLD)-of-WhatsApp-Messenger

1. Connection with Websocket Server
In WhatsApp, each active device is connected with a WebSocket server via WebSocket protocol. A WebSocket server keeps the connection open with all the active (online) users. Since one server isn’t enough to handle billions of devices, there should be enough servers to handle billions of users.
---
For 30 days, the storage capacity would become the following:
30∗10 TB/day = 300 TB/month
---
The media file is compressed and encrypted on the device side.
The compressed and encrypted file is sent to the asset service to store the file on blob storage.
The asset service assigns an ID that’s communicated with the sender. The asset service also maintains a hash for each file to avoid duplication of content on the blob storage.
For example, if a user wants to upload an image that’s already there in the blob storage, the image won’t be uploaded. Instead, the same ID is forwarded to the receiver.
The asset service sends the ID of media files to the receiver via the message service. The receiver downloads the media file from the blob storage using the ID.
The content is loaded onto a CDN if the asset service receives a large number of requests for some particular content.
---
This API is used to send a text message from a sender to a receiver by making a POST API call to the /messages API endpoint. Generally, the sender’s and receiver’s IDs are their phone numbers.

Get Message
getMessage(user_Id)

Using this API call, users can fetch all unread messages when they come online after being offline for some time.

Upload File
uploadFile(file_type, file)

We can upload media files via the uploadFile API by making a POST request to the /v1/media API endpoint. A successful response returns an ID that’s forwarded to the receiver.

Download Media File
downloadFile(user_id, file_id)
response_text:
The provided architecture design for WhatsApp Messenger is a complex system involving multiple microservices and data stores. Here's a summary of the key components and their responsibilities:

1. WebSocket Manager: This service manages connections between active users and WebSocket servers. It maintains a mapping between active users and assigned ports.
2. Message Service: This service communicates with the group service to retrieve data of Group/A users. It follows the same process as a WebSocket server and delivers messages to each user.
3. Group Service: This service keeps all information about users in each group, including user IDs, group ID, status, group icon, number of users, etc. It resides on top of a MySQL database cluster with multiple secondary replicas distributed geographically.
4. Asset Service: This service is responsible for storing and managing media files. It compresses and encrypts media files on the device side before sending them to the blob storage. It assigns an ID to each file and maintains a hash to avoid duplication of content on the blob storage.
5. Data Model Design: The data model design includes a mapping between active users and assigned ports, as well as a mapping between media files and their IDs.
6. Low-Level Design (LLD): The LLD involves using microservices architecture, with each service having ownership of its own data model. It also involves using the WebSocket protocol for connections between active users and WebSocket servers.
7. Media File Upload: Users can upload media files via the uploadFile API by making a POST request to the /v1/media API endpoint. The asset service assigns an ID to each file and forwards it to the receiver.
8. Get Message: This API call allows users to fetch all unread messages when they come online after being offline for some time.
9. Download Media File: Users can download media files via the downloadFile API by making a POST request to the /v1/media/fileID API endpoint, where fileID is the ID of the media file.

Overall, this architecture design emphasizes scalability, reliability, and security, which are crucial for a messaging platform like WhatsApp Messenger.

Designing Whatsapp Messenger | System Design
Last Updated : 18 Mar, 2024
Ever thought about how this widely-used messaging app actually works behind the scenes? This article is your guide to the system design of WhatsApp. From handling tons of messages to making sure your chats are secure, we’ll explore the technical aspects that keep this app running smoothly and managing things like managing data, keeping your messages private, and the challenges of making sure your texts arrive lightning-fast.

Designing-WhatsApp-Messenger--System-Design

Important Topics for WhatsApp System Design
response_text:
1. Connection with Websocket Server: In WhatsApp, each active device is connected to a WebSocket server via the WebSocket protocol. A WebSocket server keeps the connection open with all active (online) users. Since one server isn't enough to handle billions of devices, there should be enough servers to handle billions of users.
2. Media File Handling: When a user wants to upload an image or video, it is compressed and encrypted on their device side. The compressed and encrypted file is sent to the asset service to store the file in blob storage. The asset service assigns an ID that's communicated with the sender. The asset service also maintains a hash for each file to avoid duplication of content on the blob storage.
3. Message Handling: When user A sends a message to group A, the message service sends the message to Kafka with other specific information about the group. The message is saved there for further processing. In Kafka terminology, a group can be a topic, and the senders and receivers can be producers and consumers, respectively.
4. Data Model Design: The responsibility of each of these servers is to provide a port to every online user. The mapping between servers, ports, and users is stored in the WebSocket manager that resides on top of a cluster of the data store. In this case, that's Redis.
5. API Design: The following APIs are used in WhatsApp messaging:
* Send Message: sendMessage(message_ID, sender_ID, receiver_ID, type, text=none, media_object=none, document=none)
* Get Message: getMessage(user_Id)
* Upload File: uploadFile(file_type, file)
* Download Media File: downloadFile(user_id, file_id)
6. Security: WhatsApp ensures that messages are delivered in the order they were sent by using a queue to handle messages asynchronously. The system also employs end-to-end encryption to keep your chats private and secure.
7. Scalability: To handle billions of users, the system uses microservices architecture, which makes it easier to horizontally scale and decouple services. Each service has ownership of its own data model.
8. Load Balancing: The system uses load balancing to distribute incoming traffic across multiple servers, ensuring that no single server is overwhelmed with requests.
9. Asset Service: The asset service assigns an ID that's communicated with the sender and maintains a hash for each file to avoid duplication of content on blob storage.
10. Message Queue: A message queue is used to handle messages asynchronously, ensuring that messages are delivered in the order they were sent.

context_text:
Consistency: Messages should be delivered in the order they were sent.
Availability: The system should be highly available. However, the availability can be compromised in the interest of consistency.
Security: The system must be secure via end-to-end encryption. The end-to-end encryption ensures that only the two communicating parties can see the content of messages. Nobody in between, not even WhatsApp, should have access.
Scalability: The system should be highly scalable to support an ever-increasing number of users and messages per day.
Capacity Estimation
Storage Estimation:
100 billion messages are shared through WhatsApp per day and each message takes 100 bytes on average
100 billion/day∗100 Bytes = 10 TB/day
For 30 days, the storage capacity would become the following:
---
Bandwidth Estimation:
According to the storage capacity estimation, our service will get 10TB of data each day, giving us a bandwidth of 926 Mb/s.
10 TB/86400sec ≈ 926Mb/s

Number of servers estimation:
WhatsApp handles around 10 million connections on a single server, which seems quite high for a server.
No. of servers = Total connections per day/No. of connections per server = 2 billion/10 million = 200 servers
So, according to the above estimates, we require 200 chat servers.

High Level Design (HLD) of WhatsApp Messenger
High-Level-Design-(HLD)-of-WhatsApp-Messenger

The following steps describe the communication between both clients:
---
Important Topics for WhatsApp System Design

Requirements
Capacity Estimation
High Level Design (HLD) of WhatsApp Messenger
Data Model Design:
API Design
Low Level Design (LLD) of System Design
Approach to achieve the below system attributes
Requirements
The WhatsApp messenger design should meet below requirements:
---
Functional Requirement
Conversation: The system should support one-on-one and group conversations between users.
Acknowledgment: The system should support message delivery acknowledgment, such as sent, delivered, and read.
Sharing: The system should support sharing of media files, such as images, videos, and audio.
Chat storage: The system must support the persistent storage of chat messages when a user is offline until the successful delivery of messages.
Push notifications: The system should be able to notify offline users of new messages once their status becomes online.
Non-Functional Requirement
Low latency: Users should be able to receive messages with low latency.
Consistency: Messages should be delivered in the order they were sent.
---
Now, here comes the responsibility of the group service. The group service keeps all information about users in each group in the system. It has all the information about each group, including user IDs, group ID, status, group icon, number of users, and so on. This service resides on top of the MySQL database cluster, with multiple secondary replicas distributed geographically. A Redis cache server also exists to cache data from the MySQL servers. Both geographically distributed replicas and Redis cache aid in reducing latency.

The group message handler communicates with the group service to retrieve data of Group/A users. In the last step, the group message handler follows the same process as a WebSocket server and delivers the message to each user.
---
4. Support for Group messages
Since user A is connected to a WebSocket server, it sends a message to the message service intended for Group A.The message service sends the message to Kafka with other specific information about the group. The message is saved there for further processing. In Kafka terminology, a group can be a topic, and the senders and receivers can be producers and consumers, respectively.
---
API Design
Send message
sendMessage(message_ID, sender_ID, reciever_ID, type, text=none, media_object=none, document=none)
---
The following steps describe the communication between both clients:

User A and user B create a communication channel with the chat server.
User A sends a message to the chat server.
Upon receiving the message, the chat server acknowledges back to user A.
The chat server sends the message to user B and stores the message in the database if the receiver’s status is offline.
User B sends an acknowledgment to the chat server.
The chat server notifies user A that the message has been successfully delivered.
When user B reads the message, the application notifies the chat server.
The chat server notifies user A that user B has read the message.

Data-Model-Design
---
The responsibility of each of these servers is to provide a port to every online user. The mapping between servers, ports, and users is stored in the WebSocket manager that resides on top of a cluster of the data store. In this case, that’s Redis.

2. Send or receive messages
The WebSocket manager is responsible for maintaining a mapping between an active user and a port assigned to the user. Whenever a user is connected to another WebSocket server, this information will be updated in the data store. A WebSocket server also communicates with another service called message service.

30∗10 TB/day = 300 TB/month

This API is used to send a text message from a sender to a receiver by making a POST API call to the /messages API endpoint. Generally, the sender’s and receiver’s IDs are their phone numbers.

Get Message
getMessage(user_Id)

Using this API call, users can fetch all unread messages when they come online after being offline for some time.

uploadFile(file_type, file)

Architecture
We will be using microservices architecture since it will make it easier to horizontally scale and decouple our services. Each service will have ownership of its own data model.

Low Level Design (LLD) of System Design
Low-Level-Design(LLD)-of-WhatsApp-Messenger

1. Connection with Websocket Server
In WhatsApp, each active device is connected with a WebSocket server via WebSocket protocol. A WebSocket server keeps the connection open with all the active (online) users. Since one server isn’t enough to handle billions of devices, there should be enough servers to handle billions of users.
---
The media file is compressed and encrypted on the device side.
The compressed and encrypted file is sent to the asset service to store the file on blob storage.
The asset service assigns an ID that’s communicated with the sender. The asset service also maintains a hash for each file to avoid duplication of content on the blob storage.
For example, if a user wants to upload an image that’s already there in the blob storage, the image won’t be uploaded. Instead, the same ID is forwarded to the receiver.
The asset service sends the ID of media files to the receiver via the message service. The receiver downloads the media file from the blob storage using the ID.
The content is loaded onto a CDN if the asset service receives a large number of requests for some particular content.
response_text:
1. What are the non-functional requirements for the messaging system?

Low latency and consistency in message delivery are non-functional requirements for the messaging system. Low latency means that messages should be delivered quickly after they are sent, while consistency means that messages should be delivered in the order they were sent.

2. How does the group message handler communicate with the group service?

The group message handler communicates with the group service to retrieve data about Group/A users. It follows the same process as a WebSocket server and delivers the message to each user.

3. What is Kafka, and how does it relate to the messaging system?

Kafka is a distributed streaming platform that can handle high-volume data processing and event-driven architectures. In the messaging system, Kafka can be used as a topic where messages are saved for further processing. Senders and receivers can be producers and consumers, respectively.

4. What is the responsibility of each server in the system?

Each server in the system has the following responsibilities:

* WebSocket manager: Provides a port to every online user and maintains a mapping between active users and assigned ports.
* Data store (e.g., Redis): Stores data about active users, including their statuses.
* Message service: Communicates with the group service to retrieve data of Group/A users and delivers messages to each user.
* Asset service: Stores media files on blob storage and assigns an ID to each file.
5. How do users receive messages once their status becomes online?

Once a user's status becomes online, the message service communicates with the group service to retrieve data of Group/A users, and delivers the message to each user.

6. What is the storage capacity of the system over 30 days?

Over 30 days, the storage capacity of the system would be approximately 300 TB/month, assuming an average of 10 TB/day.

7. How do users upload media files to the system?

Users can upload media files via the uploadFile API by making a POST request to the /v1/media API endpoint. The asset service then stores the file on blob storage and assigns an ID to it. The ID is communicated with the sender.

8. How does the system handle duplication of content on the blob storage?

The asset service maintains a hash for each file to avoid duplication of content on the blob storage. If a user tries to upload an image that's already there in the blob storage, the image won't be uploaded, and the same ID is forwarded to the receiver instead.

response_text:
The given system design is for a messaging platform that supports group messages. The system consists of several microservices, including a WebSocket server, a message service, a group message handler, and an asset service. Each microservice has its own data model, and the system uses a distributed database cluster with Redis cache to store and retrieve data.

Here are some key design decisions and considerations:

1. Use of Microservices: The system uses a microservices architecture, which allows for easier scaling and decoupling of services. This is important for a messaging platform that needs to handle a large number of users and messages.
2. WebSocket Connection: Each active device is connected to a WebSocket server via the WebSocket protocol. This allows for real-time communication between devices and the system.
3. Data Storage: The system uses a distributed database cluster with Redis cache to store and retrieve data. This provides fast access to data and reduces latency.
4. Group Messages: The group message handler communicates with the group service to retrieve data of Group/A users. In Kafka terminology, a group can be a topic, and the senders and receivers can be producers and consumers, respectively.
5. Media File Upload and Download: Media files are compressed and encrypted on the device side before being sent to the asset service for storage on blob storage. The asset service assigns an ID to each file and communicates it to the receiver via the message service. Users can download media files from the blob storage using the ID.
6. Content Loading: If the asset service receives a large number of requests for some particular content, the content is loaded onto a CDN to reduce latency.
7. Data Model Design: Each microservice has its own data model, which are designed to handle the specific requirements of that service.
8. Low Latency: The system is designed to provide low latency communication between devices and the system. This is achieved through the use of a distributed database cluster and Redis cache.
9. Consistency: Messages are delivered in the order they were sent, ensuring consistency in message delivery.
10. Scalability: The system is designed to handle a large number of users and messages, making it highly scalable.

Some potential challenges and considerations for this design include:

1. Scalability: As the number of users and messages grows, the system may need to be scaled to handle the increased load. This could involve adding more servers or upgrading existing hardware.
2. Latency: The system may experience latency issues if the database cluster or Redis cache is not properly configured or if there are too many requests for data at once.
3. Data consistency: Ensuring that data is consistent across all services and databases can be challenging, especially in a distributed environment.
4. Security: Ensuring the security of sensitive data, such as user credentials and message content, is crucial. This may involve implementing encryption and authentication protocols.
5. Availability: The system must be available at all times to ensure that users can communicate with each other effectively. This may involve implementing redundancy and failover mechanisms.

It is responsible for storing and retrieving messages from the Mnesia database. It also deletes messages from the Mnesia database after a configurable amount of time. And, it exposes APIs to receive messages by various filters, such as user ID, message ID, and so on.

Using this API call, users can fetch all unread messages when they come online after being offline for some time.

Upload File
uploadFile(file_type, file)

We can upload media files via the uploadFile API by making a POST request to the /v1/media API endpoint. A successful response returns an ID that’s forwarded to the receiver.

Download Media File
downloadFile(user_id, file_id)
response_text:
The provided system design is for a messaging application with features such as group conversations, message delivery acknowledgment, sharing of media files, and push notifications. Here's a breakdown of the different components and their responsibilities:

1. WebSocket Manager:
	* Responsible for maintaining a mapping between active users and assigned ports.
	* Updates user information in the data store when a new user connects or disconnects.
2. Message Service:
	* Acts as an interface to the Mnesia database for other services interacting with the databases.
	* Stores and retrieves messages from the Mnesia database.
	* Deletes messages from the Mnesia database after a configurable amount of time.
	* Exposes APIs for receiving messages by various filters, such as user ID, message ID, etc.
3. Asset Service:
	* Responsible for sending and receiving media files.
4. Data Model Design:
	* The responsibility of each server is to provide a port to every online user.
	* Mapping between servers, ports, and users is stored in the WebSocket manager that resides on top of a cluster of the data store (Redis).
5. Functional Requirements:
	* Supports one-on-one and group conversations.
	* Supports message delivery acknowledgment, such as sent, delivered, and read.
	* Supports sharing of media files, such as images, videos, and audio.
	* Supports persistent storage of chat messages when a user is offline until the successful delivery of messages.
	* Notifies offline users of new messages once their status becomes online.
6. Non-Functional Requirements:
	* Low latency: Users should be able to receive messages with low latency.
	* Consistency: Messages should be delivered in the order they were sent.
7. Architecture:
	* Microservices architecture is used to horizontally scale and decouple services.
	* Each service has ownership of its own data model.
8. Low-Level Design (LLD):
	* Each active device is connected with a WebSocket server via the WebSocket protocol.
	* A WebSocket server keeps the connection open with all active (online) users.

Overall, this system design appears to be well-structured and scalable, with clear responsibilities assigned to each component and service. The use of microservices architecture and a distributed data store like Redis can help ensure low latency and high availability, which are critical requirements for any messaging application.

Scalability: The system should be highly scalable to support an ever-increasing number of users and messages per day.
Capacity Estimation
Storage Estimation:
100 billion messages are shared through WhatsApp per day and each message takes 100 bytes on average
100 billion/day∗100 Bytes = 10 TB/day

Bandwidth Estimation:
According to the storage capacity estimation, our service will get 10TB of data each day, giving us a bandwidth of 926 Mb/s.
10 TB/86400sec ≈ 926Mb/s

Number of servers estimation:
WhatsApp handles around 10 million connections on a single server, which seems quite high for a server.
No. of servers = Total connections per day/No. of connections per server = 2 billion/10 million = 200 servers
So, according to the above estimates, we require 200 chat servers.

The following steps describe the communication between both clients:

User A and user B create a communication channel with the chat server.
User A sends a message to the chat server.
Upon receiving the message, the chat server acknowledges back to user A.
The chat server sends the message to user B and stores the message in the database if the receiver’s status is offline.
User B sends an acknowledgment to the chat server.
The chat server notifies user A that the message has been successfully delivered.
When user B reads the message, the application notifies the chat server.
The chat server notifies user A that user B has read the message.

Low Level Design (LLD) of System Design
Low-Level-Design(LLD)-of-WhatsApp-Messenger

1. Connection with Websocket Server
In WhatsApp, each active device is connected with a WebSocket server via WebSocket protocol. A WebSocket server keeps the connection open with all the active (online) users. Since one server isn’t enough to handle billions of devices, there should be enough servers to handle billions of users.
---
The responsibility of each of these servers is to provide a port to every online user. The mapping between servers, ports, and users is stored in the WebSocket manager that resides on top of a cluster of the data store. In this case, that’s Redis.

2. Send or receive messages
The WebSocket manager is responsible for maintaining a mapping between an active user and a port assigned to the user. Whenever a user is connected to another WebSocket server, this information will be updated in the data store. A WebSocket server also communicates with another service called message service.
---
Message service is a repository of messages on top of the Mnesia database cluster. It acts as an interface to the Mnesia database for other services interacting with the databases. It is responsible for storing and retrieving messages from the Mnesia database. It also deletes messages from the Mnesia database after a configurable amount of time. And, it exposes APIs to receive messages by various filters, such as user ID, message ID, and so on.

3. Send or receive media files
We have another service called the asset service, which is responsible for sending and receiving media files.
---
Functional Requirement
Conversation: The system should support one-on-one and group conversations between users.
Acknowledgment: The system should support message delivery acknowledgment, such as sent, delivered, and read.
Sharing: The system should support sharing of media files, such as images, videos, and audio.
Chat storage: The system must support the persistent storage of chat messages when a user is offline until the successful delivery of messages.
Push notifications: The system should be able to notify offline users of new messages once their status becomes online.
Non-Functional Requirement
Low latency: Users should be able to receive messages with low latency.
Consistency: Messages should be delivered in the order they were sent.

Architecture

Low-Level-Design(LLD)-of-WhatsApp-Messenger

1. Connection with Websocket Server
In WhatsApp, each active device is connected with a WebSocket server via WebSocket protocol. A WebSocket server keeps the connection open with all the active (online) users. Since one server isn’t enough to handle billions of devices, there should be enough servers to handle billions of users.
---
The media file is compressed and encrypted on the device side.
The compressed and encrypted file is sent to the asset service to store the file on blob storage.
The asset service assigns an ID that’s communicated with the sender. The asset service also maintains a hash for each file to avoid duplication of content on the blob storage.
For example, if a user wants to upload an image that’s already there in the blob storage, the image won’t be uploaded. Instead, the same ID is forwarded to the receiver.
The asset service sends the ID of media files to the receiver via the message service. The receiver downloads the media file from the blob storage using the ID.
The content is loaded onto a CDN if the asset service receives a large number of requests for some particular content.
---
Message service is a repository of messages on top of the Mnesia database cluster. It acts as an interface to the Mnesia database for other services interacting with the databases. It is responsible for storing and retrieving messages from the Mnesia database. It also deletes messages from the Mnesia database after a configurable amount of time. And, it exposes APIs to receive messages by various filters, such as user ID, message ID, and so on.

3. Send or receive media files
We have another service called the asset service, which is responsible for sending and receiving media files.

	* Acts as the connection hub for all active users in the system.
	* Handles communication between clients and the message service.
	* Maintains a mapping of active users to their corresponding ports.
2. Message Service:
	* Responsible for storing and retrieving messages from the Mnesia database cluster.
	* Exposes APIs for receiving messages based on user ID, message ID, and other filters.
	* Deletes messages from the Mnesia database after a configurable amount of time.
3. Asset Service:
	* Handles media file uploads and downloads.
	* Compresses and encrypts media files on the device side.
	* Stores media files in blob storage with a unique ID.
	* Sends the ID of media files to the receiver via the message service.
4. Mnesia Database Cluster:
	* Stores messages and media files for retrieval by the message service.
5. Redis Cache Server:
	* Caches data from the MySQL database cluster to reduce latency.
6. MySQL Database Cluster:
	* Stores user information, group details, and other metadata for the WhatsApp messaging system.
7. Kafka:
	* Acts as a message broker for group messages.
	* Receives messages from the message service and stores them in a topic.
	* Handles message delivery to users in the group.

Low-Level Design (LLD) of System Design:

1. Connection with Websocket Server:
	* Each active user establishes a connection with the WebSocket server via the WebSocket protocol.
	* The WebSocket server maintains a mapping of active users to their corresponding ports.
2. Messaging Process:
	* When a user sends a message, it is stored in the Mnesia database by the message service.
	* The message service sends the message to the Kafka topic for delivery to the intended recipients.
	* Each recipient retrieves the message from the Kafka topic and stores it in their local cache.
3. Media File Upload/Download:
	* When a user uploads a media file, it is compressed and encrypted on the device side.
	* The asset service stores the media file in blob storage with a unique ID.
	* The asset service sends the ID of the media file to the receiver via the message service.
4. Message Filtering:
	* The message service filters messages based on user ID, message ID, and other filters.
	* Messages that pass the filtering criteria are stored in the Mnesia database for delivery to the intended recipients.
5. Message Delivery:
	* When a recipient connects to the WebSocket server, they retrieve their unread messages from the Mnesia database.
	* The message service delivers the messages to the recipient’s WebSocket client for display.
6. Media File Playback:
	* When a user wants to play back media files, the asset service loads the file onto a Content Delivery Network (CDN) if necessary.
	* The CDN handles the distribution of the media file to users.

In summary, the WhatsApp messaging system is designed to provide a scalable and reliable communication platform for billions of users. By using microservices architecture, we can horizontally scale individual services without affecting the overall system performance.

context_text:
Consistency: Messages should be delivered in the order they were sent.
Availability: The system should be highly available. However, the availability can be compromised in the interest of consistency.
Security: The system must be secure via end-to-end encryption. The end-to-end encryption ensures that only the two communicating parties can see the content of messages. Nobody in between, not even WhatsApp, should have access.
Scalability: The system should be highly scalable to support an ever-increasing number of users and messages per day.
Capacity Estimation
Storage Estimation:
100 billion messages are shared through WhatsApp per day and each message takes 100 bytes on average
100 billion/day∗100 Bytes = 10 TB/day
For 30 days, the storage capacity would become the following:
---
Bandwidth Estimation:
According to the storage capacity estimation, our service will get 10TB of data each day, giving us a bandwidth of 926 Mb/s.
10 TB/86400sec ≈ 926Mb/s

Number of servers estimation:
WhatsApp handles around 10 million connections on a single server, which seems quite high for a server.
No. of servers = Total connections per day/No. of connections per server = 2 billion/10 million = 200 servers
So, according to the above estimates, we require 200 chat servers.

The following steps describe the communication between both clients:

User A and user B create a communication channel with the chat server.
User A sends a message to the chat server.
Upon receiving the message, the chat server acknowledges back to user A.
The chat server sends the message to user B and stores the message in the database if the receiver’s status is offline.
User B sends an acknowledgment to the chat server.
The chat server notifies user A that the message has been successfully delivered.
When user B reads the message, the application notifies the chat server.
The chat server notifies user A that user B has read the message.

The responsibility of each of these servers is to provide a port to every online user. The mapping between servers, ports, and users is stored in the WebSocket manager that resides on top of a cluster of the data store. In this case, that’s Redis.

2. Send or receive messages
The WebSocket manager is responsible for maintaining a mapping between an active user and a port assigned to the user. Whenever a user is connected to another WebSocket server, this information will be updated in the data store. A WebSocket server also communicates with another service called message service.

Functional Requirement
Conversation: The system should support one-on-one and group conversations between users.
Acknowledgment: The system should support message delivery acknowledgment, such as sent, delivered, and read.
Sharing: The system should support sharing of media files, such as images, videos, and audio.
Chat storage: The system must support the persistent storage of chat messages when a user is offline until the successful delivery of messages.
Push notifications: The system should be able to notify offline users of new messages once their status becomes online.
Non-Functional Requirement
Low latency: Users should be able to receive messages with low latency.
Consistency: Messages should be delivered in the order they were sent.

Architecture
We will be using microservices architecture since it will make it easier to horizontally scale and decouple our services. Each service will have ownership of its own data model.

Low Level Design (LLD) of System Design
Low-Level-Design(LLD)-of-WhatsApp-Messenger

1. Connection with Websocket Server
In WhatsApp, each active device is connected with a WebSocket server via WebSocket protocol. A WebSocket server keeps the connection open with all the active (online) users. Since one server isn’t enough to handle billions of devices, there should be enough servers to handle billions of users.
---
The media file is compressed and encrypted on the device side.
The compressed and encrypted file is sent to the asset service to store the file on blob storage.
The asset service assigns an ID that’s communicated with the sender. The asset service also maintains a hash for each file to avoid duplication of content on the blob storage.
For example, if a user wants to upload an image that’s already there in the blob storage, the image won’t be uploaded. Instead, the same ID is forwarded to the receiver.
The asset service sends the ID of media files to the receiver via the message service. The receiver downloads the media file from the blob storage using the ID.
The content is loaded onto a CDN if the asset service receives a large number of requests for some particular content.
---
This API is used to send a text message from a sender to a receiver by making a POST API call to the /messages API endpoint. Generally, the sender’s and receiver’s IDs are their phone numbers.

Get Message
getMessage(user_Id)

Using this API call, users can fetch all unread messages when they come online after being offline for some time.

Upload File
uploadFile(file_type, file)

We can upload media files via the uploadFile API by making a POST request to the /v1/media API endpoint. A successful response returns an ID that’s forwarded to the receiver.

Download Media File
downloadFile(user_id, file_id)
response_text:
The system you have described is a messaging platform for online users, with features such as one-on-one and group conversations, message delivery acknowledgment, sharing of media files, and push notifications. Here are some possible design patterns and architectures that could be used to implement this system:

1. Microservices Architecture:
As you mentioned, a microservices architecture would make it easier to horizontally scale and decouple the services. Each service could have ownership of its own data model, and communicate with other services via APIs.
2. Load Balancer:
To handle a large number of active users, a load balancer could be used to distribute incoming connections across multiple WebSocket servers. This would ensure that no single server is overwhelmed with connections.
3. Message Queue:
To handle the delivery of messages, a message queue could be used to store and deliver messages in order. When a user sends a message, it could be added to the message queue, and when the recipient connects, the messages could be retrieved from the queue and delivered to them.
4. Asset Service:
To handle media file uploads and downloading, an asset service could be used to store the files on blob storage. The asset service could assign a unique ID to each file, and communicate this ID to the sender and recipient. When the recipient downloads the file, they could use the ID to retrieve the file from the asset service.
5. Content Delivery Network (CDN):
To improve performance, a CDN could be used to load media files onto a network of servers around the world. This would reduce the latency for users accessing the media files from different locations.
6. Database:
A database could be used to store user information, such as phone numbers and message history. The database could also be used to handle offline messages, by storing messages when a user is offline and delivering them once they come online again.
7. WebSocket Protocol:
To handle real-time communication between users, the WebSocket protocol could be used to establish a persistent connection between the client and server. This would allow for low latency communication and message delivery acknowledgment.
8. Push Notifications:
To notify offline users of new messages, push notifications could be used to deliver the messages as soon as they become available. The push notifications could be handled by a third-party service or integrated with the messaging platform directly.
9. Security:
To ensure security, encryption could be used to protect the messages and media files during transmission. Additionally, authentication and authorization could be implemented to ensure that only authorized users can access the system.
10. Scalability:
To handle a large number of users, the system should be designed for scalability. This could involve using load balancers, horizontal scaling, and sharding to distribute the workload across multiple servers.

Overall, the design pattern and architecture used will depend on the specific requirements of the messaging platform and the traffic it is expected to handle.

We will be using microservices architecture since it will make it easier to horizontally scale and decouple our services. Each service will have ownership of its own data model.

Low Level Design (LLD) of System Design
Low-Level-Design(LLD)-of-WhatsApp-Messenger

1. Connection with Websocket Server
In WhatsApp, each active device is connected with a WebSocket server via WebSocket protocol. A WebSocket server keeps the connection open with all the active (online) users. Since one server isn’t enough to handle billions of devices, there should be enough servers to handle billions of users.
---
Functional Requirement
Conversation: The system should support one-on-one and group conversations between users.
Acknowledgment: The system should support message delivery acknowledgment, such as sent, delivered, and read.
Sharing: The system should support sharing of media files, such as images, videos, and audio.
Chat storage: The system must support the persistent storage of chat messages when a user is offline until the successful delivery of messages.
Push notifications: The system should be able to notify offline users of new messages once their status becomes online.
Non-Functional Requirement
Low latency: Users should be able to receive messages with low latency.
Consistency: Messages should be delivered in the order they were sent.
---
The media file is compressed and encrypted on the device side.
The compressed and encrypted file is sent to the asset service to store the file on blob storage.
The asset service assigns an ID that’s communicated with the sender. The asset service also maintains a hash for each file to avoid duplication of content on the blob storage.
For example, if a user wants to upload an image that’s already there in the blob storage, the image won’t be uploaded. Instead, the same ID is forwarded to the receiver.
The asset service sends the ID of media files to the receiver via the message service. The receiver downloads the media file from the blob storage using the ID.
The content is loaded onto a CDN if the asset service receives a large number of requests for some particular content.
---
This API is used to send a text message from a sender to a receiver by making a POST API call to the /messages API endpoint. Generally, the sender’s and receiver’s IDs are their phone numbers.

Get Message
getMessage(user_Id)

Using this API call, users can fetch all unread messages when they come online after being offline for some time.

Upload File
uploadFile(file_type, file)

We can upload media files via the uploadFile API by making a POST request to the /v1/media API endpoint. A successful response returns an ID that’s forwarded to the receiver.

Download Media File
downloadFile(user_id, file_id)
response_text:
The system design you provided is for a messaging platform with features such as one-on-one and group conversations, sharing of media files, and push notifications. Here are some observations and questions based on the information provided:

 Observations:

1. The system seems to be designed for a large number of users, with multiple WebSocket servers handling connections from active users. This suggests that the system is designed to scale horizontally.
2. The system uses a microservices architecture, with each service responsible for its own data model. This allows for greater flexibility and scalability in the system.
3. The system appears to use Redis as a cache server to reduce latency. This is a common pattern in modern web applications, as Redis can provide fast caching and message handling capabilities.
4. The system uses Kafka as a message broker for sending messages between services. Kafka is a popular choice for message brokering due to its ability to handle high volumes of messages and its scalability.
5. The system seems to have a clear separation of concerns, with each service handling a specific aspect of the messaging platform (e.g., WebSocket server handles connections, message service handles message routing).

 Questions:

1. How does the system handle message delivery failures? For example, if a user's connection is lost during message transmission, how will the message be retried or resent?
2. How does the system manage the storage of chat messages when a user goes offline? It seems that the system stores the messages in Redis, but how does it ensure that the messages are not lost when the user comes back online?
3. Can you provide more details on how the system handles push notifications for offline users? For example, how does the system determine which messages to notify the user about and how does it handle multiple messages arriving at the same time?
4. How does the system ensure data consistency across multiple WebSocket servers and Kafka brokers? For example, if a message is sent from one server but not received by another due to network issues, how does the system handle this inconsistency?
5. Can you provide more details on the data model used by each service in the system? How do the services communicate with each other, and what kind of data are they exchanging?

context_text:
Consistency: Messages should be delivered in the order they were sent.
Availability: The system should be highly available. However, the availability can be compromised in the interest of consistency.
Security: The system must be secure via end-to-end encryption. The end-to-end encryption ensures that only the two communicating parties can see the content of messages. Nobody in between, not even WhatsApp, should have access.
Scalability: The system should be highly scalable to support an ever-increasing number of users and messages per day.
Capacity Estimation
Storage Estimation:
100 billion messages are shared through WhatsApp per day and each message takes 100 bytes on average
100 billion/day∗100 Bytes = 10 TB/day
For 30 days, the storage capacity would become the following:
---
Bandwidth Estimation:
According to the storage capacity estimation, our service will get 10TB of data each day, giving us a bandwidth of 926 Mb/s.
10 TB/86400sec ≈ 926Mb/s

Number of servers estimation:
WhatsApp handles around 10 million connections on a single server, which seems quite high for a server.
No. of servers = Total connections per day/No. of connections per server = 2 billion/10 million = 200 servers
So, according to the above estimates, we require 200 chat servers.

Requirements
The WhatsApp messenger design should meet below requirements:
---
Functional Requirement
Conversation: The system should support one-on-one and group conversations between users.
Acknowledgment: The system should support message delivery acknowledgment, such as sent, delivered, and read.
Sharing: The system should support sharing of media files, such as images, videos, and audio.
Chat storage: The system must support the persistent storage of chat messages when a user is offline until the successful delivery of messages.
Push notifications: The system should be able to notify offline users of new messages once their status becomes online.
Non-Functional Requirement
Low latency: Users should be able to receive messages with low latency.
Consistency: Messages should be delivered in the order they were sent.
---
Now, here comes the responsibility of the group service. The group service keeps all information about users in each group in the system. It has all the information about each group, including user IDs, group ID, status, group icon, number of users, and so on. This service resides on top of the MySQL database cluster, with multiple secondary replicas distributed geographically. A Redis cache server also exists to cache data from the MySQL servers. Both geographically distributed replicas and Redis cache aid in reducing latency.

The group message handler communicates with the group service to retrieve data of Group/A users. In the last step, the group message handler follows the same process as a WebSocket server and delivers the message to each user.
---
4. Support for Group messages
Since user A is connected to a WebSocket server, it sends a message to the message service intended for Group A.The message service sends the message to Kafka with other specific information about the group. The message is saved there for further processing. In Kafka terminology, a group can be a topic, and the senders and receivers can be producers and consumers, respectively.
---
API Design
Send message
sendMessage(message_ID, sender_ID, reciever_ID, type, text=none, media_object=none, document=none)
---
The following steps describe the communication between both clients:

User A and user B create a communication channel with the chat server.
User A sends a message to the chat server.
Upon receiving the message, the chat server acknowledges back to user A.
The chat server sends the message to user B and stores the message in the database if the receiver’s status is offline.
User B sends an acknowledgment to the chat server.
The chat server notifies user A that the message has been successfully delivered.
When user B reads the message, the application notifies the chat server.
The chat server notifies user A that user B has read the message.

Architecture
We will be using microservices architecture since it will make it easier to horizontally scale and decouple our services. Each service will have ownership of its own data model.

Low Level Design (LLD) of System Design
Low-Level-Design(LLD)-of-WhatsApp-Messenger

1. Connection with Websocket Server
In WhatsApp, each active device is connected with a WebSocket server via WebSocket protocol. A WebSocket server keeps the connection open with all the active (online) users. Since one server isn’t enough to handle billions of devices, there should be enough servers to handle billions of users.
---
The responsibility of each of these servers is to provide a port to every online user. The mapping between servers, ports, and users is stored in the WebSocket manager that resides on top of a cluster of the data store. In this case, that’s Redis.

2. Send or receive messages
The WebSocket manager is responsible for maintaining a mapping between an active user and a port assigned to the user. Whenever a user is connected to another WebSocket server, this information will be updated in the data store. A WebSocket server also communicates with another service called message service.
---
For 30 days, the storage capacity would become the following:
30∗10 TB/day = 300 TB/month
---
The media file is compressed and encrypted on the device side.
The compressed and encrypted file is sent to the asset service to store the file on blob storage.
The asset service assigns an ID that’s communicated with the sender. The asset service also maintains a hash for each file to avoid duplication of content on the blob storage.
For example, if a user wants to upload an image that’s already there in the blob storage, the image won’t be uploaded. Instead, the same ID is forwarded to the receiver.
The asset service sends the ID of media files to the receiver via the message service. The receiver downloads the media file from the blob storage using the ID.
The content is loaded onto a CDN if the asset service receives a large number of requests for some particular content.
---
This API is used to send a text message from a sender to a receiver by making a POST API call to the /messages API endpoint. Generally, the sender’s and receiver’s IDs are their phone numbers.

Get Message
getMessage(user_Id)

Using this API call, users can fetch all unread messages when they come online after being offline for some time.

Upload File
uploadFile(file_type, file)

We can upload media files via the uploadFile API by making a POST request to the /v1/media API endpoint. A successful response returns an ID that’s forwarded to the receiver.

response_text:
Responsibility of Group Service:
The group service is responsible for storing information about users in each group, including user IDs, group ID, status, group icon, number of users, and so on. The group service resides on top of a MySQL database cluster with multiple secondary replicas distributed geographically. Additionally, there is a Redis cache server that caches data from the MySQL servers to reduce latency.

The group message handler communicates with the group service to retrieve data about Group/A users. It follows the same process as a WebSocket server and delivers the message to each user. The group service is responsible for maintaining the mapping between active users and their assigned ports, which are stored in the WebSocket manager.

Functional Requirements:

* Low latency: Users should be able to receive messages with low latency.
* Consistency: Messages should be delivered in the order they were sent.

Non-Functional Requirements:

* High availability: The system should be available and accessible at all times, even during high traffic or maintenance periods.
* Scalability: The system should be able to handle a large number of users and messages without compromising performance.
* Security: The system should protect user data and prevent unauthorized access or tampering with messages.

API Design:
The API design includes the following endpoints:

* Send message: This endpoint sends a message from a sender to a receiver using the WebSocket protocol.
* Get message: This endpoint fetches all unread messages for a particular user when they come online after being offline for some time.
* Upload file: This endpoint allows users to upload media files, which are stored on blob storage.
* Download file: This endpoint allows users to download media files from blob storage using the ID provided by the asset service.

Data Model Design:
The data model includes the following entities:

* User
* Group
* Message
* Media File

Architecture:
The architecture consists of microservices, each with its own data model. The WebSocket manager is responsible for maintaining the mapping between active users and their assigned ports, which are stored in the Redis cache. The media file is compressed and encrypted on the device side before being sent to the asset service for storage on blob storage. The asset service assigns an ID to each media file and communicates it to the receiver via the message service.

Low-Level Design (LLD):
The LLD includes the following components:

* WebSocket protocol: Each active device is connected to a WebSocket server via WebSocket protocol.
* Redis cache: The WebSocket manager uses Redis cache to store the mapping between active users and their assigned ports.
* Blob storage: Media files are stored on blob storage, which is assigned an ID by the asset service.
* Message service: The message service communicates with the asset service to provide the ID of media files to receivers.

Based on the provided context and question, my answer is:

Response: Judgement: <yes> Delivery acknowledgment is supported in WhatsApp messaging.

Explanation: In WhatsApp, message delivery acknowledgment is provided to users through push notifications. When a user sends a message, they receive a notification indicating that the message has been sent. Similarly, when a user receives a message, they receive a notification indicating that the message has been delivered. This provides a consistent and low-latency messaging experience for users.

High Level Design (HLD) of WhatsApp Messenger
High-Level-Design-(HLD)-of-WhatsApp-Messenger

The following steps describe the communication between both clients:
---
Important Topics for WhatsApp System Design

Requirements
Capacity Estimation
High Level Design (HLD) of WhatsApp Messenger
Data Model Design:
API Design
Low Level Design (LLD) of System Design
Approach to achieve the below system attributes
Requirements
The WhatsApp messenger design should meet below requirements:
---
Functional Requirement
Conversation: The system should support one-on-one and group conversations between users.
Acknowledgment: The system should support message delivery acknowledgment, such as sent, delivered, and read.
Sharing: The system should support sharing of media files, such as images, videos, and audio.
Chat storage: The system must support the persistent storage of chat messages when a user is offline until the successful delivery of messages.
Push notifications: The system should be able to notify offline users of new messages once their status becomes online.
Non-Functional Requirement
Low latency: Users should be able to receive messages with low latency.
Consistency: Messages should be delivered in the order they were sent.
---
Now, here comes the responsibility of the group service. The group service keeps all information about users in each group in the system. It has all the information about each group, including user IDs, group ID, status, group icon, number of users, and so on. This service resides on top of the MySQL database cluster, with multiple secondary replicas distributed geographically. A Redis cache server also exists to cache data from the MySQL servers. Both geographically distributed replicas and Redis cache aid in reducing latency.

The group message handler communicates with the group service to retrieve data of Group/A users. In the last step, the group message handler follows the same process as a WebSocket server and delivers the message to each user.
---
4. Support for Group messages
Since user A is connected to a WebSocket server, it sends a message to the message service intended for Group A.The message service sends the message to Kafka with other specific information about the group. The message is saved there for further processing. In Kafka terminology, a group can be a topic, and the senders and receivers can be producers and consumers, respectively.
---
API Design
Send message
sendMessage(message_ID, sender_ID, reciever_ID, type, text=none, media_object=none, document=none)
---
The following steps describe the communication between both clients:

User A and user B create a communication channel with the chat server.
User A sends a message to the chat server.
Upon receiving the message, the chat server acknowledges back to user A.
The chat server sends the message to user B and stores the message in the database if the receiver’s status is offline.
User B sends an acknowledgment to the chat server.
The chat server notifies user A that the message has been successfully delivered.
When user B reads the message, the application notifies the chat server.
The chat server notifies user A that user B has read the message.
Data Model Design:
Data-Model-Design

The responsibility of each of these servers is to provide a port to every online user. The mapping between servers, ports, and users is stored in the WebSocket manager that resides on top of a cluster of the data store. In this case, that’s Redis.

2. Send or receive messages
The WebSocket manager is responsible for maintaining a mapping between an active user and a port assigned to the user. Whenever a user is connected to another WebSocket server, this information will be updated in the data store. A WebSocket server also communicates with another service called message service.

Message service is a repository of messages on top of the Mnesia database cluster. It acts as an interface to the Mnesia database for other services interacting with the databases. It is responsible for storing and retrieving messages from the Mnesia database. It also deletes messages from the Mnesia database after a configurable amount of time. And, it exposes APIs to receive messages by various filters, such as user ID, message ID, and so on.
